summary: This is an email forwarding a sealed letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Nathan regarding proposed redactions and sealing in the case United States v. Maxwell. It concerns a motion to modify a protective order and includes attachments with sealed and public versions of the government's response.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Maxwell, to whom the government's sealed letter regarding redactions and sealing is addressed.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Author of the responsive letter to the court regarding proposed redactions and sealing of documents related to a protective order modification motion in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Defense counsel
persons.context: Copied on the email and the government's letter regarding the sealing and redaction proposals in the Maxwell case.

connections.description: Prosecutor submitting a sealed letter and proposed redactions to the presiding judge regarding a court order.
Defense attorney is a party in the case before Judge Nathan and is copied on correspondence regarding procedural matters.
Opposing parties in the criminal case, with the prosecution copying defense on procedural correspondence to the court.

events.title: Court Order on Redactions
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order directing the parties to propose redactions to letter briefing regarding the defendant's motion to modify the protective order.

events.title: Government Submits Sealed Response
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office submits a sealed letter with Exhibit A to Judge Nathan, proposing redactions and requesting sealing, and files a redacted public version.

keyFacts: The document is part of the case United States v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), indicating ongoing legal proceedings against Ghislaine Maxwell in August 2020.
The government is responding to a court order regarding a defense motion to modify a protective order, highlighting disputes over document secrecy.
The government submitted both a sealed version (with Exhibit A) and a redacted public version of its letter, indicating sensitive information is being withheld from public view.
The correspondence shows procedural activity, with the prosecution coordinating with the court and copying defense counsel on sealing and redaction proposals.
